name: O-Phosphoethanolamine

The fundamental structure can be thought of as ethanolamine, which provides a basis for estimation. Looking at the functional groups: the phosphate group (P(O)(OH)2) can significantly increase the melting point due to its ability to form strong hydrogen bonds and increase molecular weight; the hydroxyl group (OH) can also contribute to hydrogen bonding, increasing the melting point; the amino group (NH2) can both donate and accept hydrogen bonds, which will further increase the melting point. Prediction: 410 (170 for the base ethanolamine structure + 200 for the phosphate group + 30 for the hydroxyl group + 10 for the amino group)

name: O-Phosphoethanolamine

- Basic unit, ethanol: boiling point around 78°C. However, the molecule in question is not just ethanol but has additional groups affecting the melting point. 
- The presence of the phosphate group (PO(OH)2) leads to increased hydrogen bonding capabilities, thus significantly raising the melting point. This could contribute to an increase of approximately +150°C over ethanol. 
- The amino group (NH2) also participates in hydrogen bonding, potentially adding around +20°C. 
- The -OH group could contribute an additional +30°C increase due to hydrogen bonding. 
- Considering that both phosphate and hydroxyl groups enhance the hydrogen bonding greatly, they have substantial effects that might even be synergistic. Yet, the given increases are conservative estimates based on the typical effects observed for these functional groups in other compounds. 
- It should also be noted that the molecule will likely have a more rigid structure due to its multiple functional groups, which also contributes to an increased melting point.
